intro: Anemone pulsatilla subsp. grandis, commonly known as the Pasque flower, is a herbaceous perennial native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink and are often tinged with purple. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features basal leaves that are palmately divided with lobes that are usually hairy. It thrives in well-drained, alkaline soils and is often found in meadows, grasslands, and rocky areas. The flowers bloom in early spring, making it one of the first plants to emerge after winter.
